comments.commentBody:
Wait. Did the prosecutors (the assistant US Attorneys of SDNY) ever go on record and express that? Since you are not pointing us to anything remotely like that, I am guessing no.

It is true that the FBI might have told him something to that effect at some point during the multi-year investigation. But the FBI is not the ones who prosecuted him. The super-hot US Attorneys of SDNY did.

A newspaper can speculate, opine or posit all it wants. It is what they do. And it serves its readership.

Mr. Steward performed a blockbuster analysis of the history of lying and cheating. He shed light on how the Harvard Law cheating came to light. But above all, he shows us once and for all that the insider trading was not an isolated lapse of judgment by someone who has otherwise led a life of integrity. If it reads like a crime thriller, that is just gravy.

(Continued) The Affordable Care Act makes American workers more mobile, and increases the competition for labor. That is a slight redressing of the balance between labor and capital, and most appropriate after three decades in which workers have not received an equitable share in the productivity gains that they have created.

Douthat correctly flags an emerging conundrum: how will we create sufficient jobs as labor requirements diminish due to rising computerization and mechanization? My tentative solution is to tax capital more heavily and to use the resulting revenue to create jobs in infrastructure repair and development, education, the arts and health care. We'd all be the better for such an approach.

Despite feminism having lost its earlier fervour and bite, Gloria's reaffirmation of faith in feminism and its future, experienced as she did at the JLF,  couldn't really be misplaced. For, until societies do continue denying due space to women under the spurious cultural bias born out of the male tilting gendered power relations, feminism  would keep attracting new votaries and activists, may be with changed ideological nuance, to feminism.

Pope Francis has brilliantly highlighted the Church's mission as one of bringing succor to those given little consideration by secular society: the disabled, the sick and, especially, the poor.

I applaud Pope Francis for speaking truth to power and for reminding us all that a key part of our mission as human beings is to improve the circumstances of our fellows. This is a message that has been weakened in recent decades as the world has increased its focus on the pursuit of profit.

Pope Francis has observed, correctly, that 'trickle-down' economics has not worked. The Pope is right that inclusive economies are imperative. I admire Pope for using his pulpit so effectively and morally.

The ecological needs of Gaza, the West Bank and Israel demonstrate compellingly and urgently the need for peace in this troubled region. I am sure that economic needs point to the same conclusion.

Peace will propel regional economic growth, investment and progress on the energy and environmental fronts more comprehensively than any other strategy. I hope that the leaders of Gaza, Palestine and Israel will come to a cooperative settlement that will allow their peoples a chance to grow and heal.

“He was either very lucky or very strategic,”
Or a different scenario. A whole bunch of spooks were very unlucky, very stupid, incompetent or suffered from a superiority complex, at the NSA complex.

"Mr. Snowden appears to have set the parameters for the searches, including which subjects to look for and how deeply to follow links to documents and other data on the N.S.A.’s internal networks. Intelligence officials told a House hearing last week that he accessed roughly 1.7 million files."

Wait, don't tell me. Did he set it to extend its data collection two to three hops from each target of interest?
I sure as heck would vote to convict him.

"stealing government documents": this NY Times reader would vote to convict in less than a NY minute.
Most jurors understand that while the victim may have had it coming, murder is murder. And, the presumably 'liberal' Ny Times readership grasps that whether one approves of x policy of y administration, scaling the fence at the White House to protest it is 1) still trespass and 2) is going get you in jail.
Oh, I don't know. Peruse these comments and I bet you'll be able to find twelve or more bloody-minded individuals who would stop at nothing to convict Snowden of high treason and worse.
I doubt that the government could assemble 12 jurors who would vote to convict Snowden of anything. Certainly, they couldn't find that many NYT readers who would vote to convict.
Google and all of the rest of the force data suppliers did not like their marching orders from the NSA.....who is to say they (Google or others) did not provide the bots?

Fascinating. Where do you find that he shopped our information to China, Russia, et al.? Or did you just make that up based on no evidence whatsoever?

He did release information to the press, and many are grateful to learn what our government has been up to---and apparently our government is backing down a lot once their deeds are exposed (e.g., tapping the phone of the heads of state of our allies).

Of course, if you can point to evidence that Snowden has shopped "our" information to Russia and China, my apologies. But I don't think you can.

History shows that too much secrecy is a bigger hazard than too little.

Thought experiment: What if just before we went into Vietnam and Iraq, someone leaked all our intelligence about these countries. There is a good chance the outcry would have opposed the lies which justified these stupid/criminal wars.

A lot of that is just cheap content, whatever they can get free or near free to put on between commercials.  They eliminated the budget for reporting.  They choose carefully among what is really cheap for what gets audience reaction, such as "aw, that's cute" or pictures of big storms.  There are two sides to profit, raise income, and reduce expense.  They eliminated any content they would pay for.

He didn't claim he had access. He claimed he had the "authority" to do so.

"I, sitting at my desk, certainly had the authorities to wiretap anyone from you or your accountant to a federal judge to even the president if I had a personal email."

This is clearly illegal. His statement is clearly false. I think this gives you a very good insight into how Snowden thinks.

This is consistent with Snowden's very first testimony -- that he or 'anyone' can have access to anything - the 'President's email. ' Why should a Snowden Robot be any different?  I should be disappointed with his skills if he didn't use a program.  So how is this news?  Snowden is not really the point.  And, how is a "he exploited our open fannies" a justification of *anything*?  This is still just plain wrong and Orwellian-ly absurd: "to preserve freedom we must sacrifice liberty."  Guess this puts me in the digital precognetics radar, eh?  Don't give me up, Mr. Sulzberger, please!

Being unprepared is a feature, not a problem.  It is why they can get these people to come on.  It is also cheap.  No cost to prepare, then bring on a mental lightweight who will ramp up the emotions.

We don't have to look at conspiracy theories. The information revealed by Snowden shows that the NSA is indeed actively violating the Bill of Rights, specifically the Fourth Amendment, of every American on a regular basis.

It's rather Orwellian to claim that those who are involved in these violations are "just as committed to liberty." They have to violate our rights to save them?

The mixed reaction to these disclosures is not so much a sign of political polarization (in fact, there is unprecedented bipartisan agreement among the "liberals" and conservatives on this issue). Rather, it is a disturbing willingness among a large portion of the U.S. population (again, on both sides of the partisan divide) to sacrifice their liberties for the illusion of safety.

No, I do not believe it is at all benign.  I believe that poverty and inequality has gotten so bad, we are ripe for revolution and the government knows it. So rather than  correct the issues, they will spy on everyone and quietly arrest the "troublemakers".

It doesn't matter whether people within the NSA grasp how "frightening" it is to be spied upon. What matters is whether people within the NSA understand the Constitutional boundaries on spying
on American citizens. And, it would help if anyone involved in this mess- NSA or government contractors- had an iota of competence in running these systems. Exactly who were the geniuses who hired Snowden? They have the judgement and insight of two year olds.

People within government and especially the NSA seem to view Americans opposed to their covert activities as reckless if not unpatriotic. Conversely, many of us on the outside act as though we believe that the NSA is a nothing but a covert conspiracy to destroy the Bill of Rights. Might the truth about all parties be more benign? Might there be some way for people in the NSA to really grasp how frightening  it is to be spied upon and likewise,  could some of us who oppose the activity at least recognize that many people within the NSA are just as committed to liberty as we are?

Doubling the minimum wage is a recipe for disaster. The last thing the country needs is a move like LA's.

Haven't Americans been through enough government-driven disruptions? Our economy is still in the throes of Obamacare changes. With another mandate about to hit, another group of Americans is about to undergo a major disruption in its coverage. People are still finding out who their doctors are and which hospitals they'll wind up at. And then there's the sticker shock of the deductibles.

How much can Americans be expected to absorb? There's a reason polls show Americans feel government is too big and/or intrusive. They've reached their limit. We do not need any more grand, disruptive and poorly thought-through utopian solutions that produce a host of unintended consequences and that ignore all warnings.

Andrea:  a few years ago Democrat and liberal were labels to avoid. "Government" may be another Luhntian dirty word in your mind, but most people, including corporate welfare queens find that government has some redeeming social value.  The fact that government has shrunk under the current Democratic administration, even with the growth in the defense and security sectors is not something conservatives like to acknowledge. The fact that cash subsidies and tax credits for the poor tend to lessen the need for government bureaucracy is also ignored by those who are repulsed by the idea of healthy young men not being forced to, "Get a job!"  Reality is increasingly harder to grok for those who just prefer things as they were.

To AndreaE: I am most certainly not in favor of a larger, more intrusive government. But the so-called 'conservative' alternative -- no minimum wage, no food subsidies, no child subsidies, health care only for those who can afford it -- is worse by several orders of magnitude.

The so-called 'conservative' view is distinctly, distastefully radical, and it is entirely out of touch with the reality on the ground. Boot the radicals out, regain a true conservative footing, and you will win me back.

AndreaE,
We can't go back to Jeffersonian small government. We're not a bunch of small farmers who don't need help anymore. We have highways, telecommunication systems, railways, power grids, the internet and many other interdependent systems that must be maintained in order to live in this crowded world we live in.

Intrusive government is and probably will be a problem we have to deal with. But that's no an excuse to force people to work in jobs they only keep to get insurance. What kind of freedom is that?

Notice how it is becoming increasingly harder for those who try to maintain some semblance of reasonableness and feel compelled to act as apologists for the increasingly ludicrous, inhumane and just plain selfish policies of conservatives these days?
1) People who voluntarily elect to reduce their hours somewhat are the ones who can afford to, not the ones getting by on subsistence-level wages. Even more so for those taking early retirement.
2) Subsidized health care causing people to work less is just a modern version of one of the Republican's favorite Big Lies: welfare queens driving around in Cadillacs. The subsidy for a couple who are 50 years old, with a combined earning of $50,000 a year is about $300 per month. The subsidy for the same couple if they make $35,000 is under $500. Does anyone really believe a $2400 cut in tax credits would encourage that couple to forego $15,000 in earnings?

It's the same tired story of Republicans howling that employers won't hire workers if taxes are slightly higher, or if they are scared about "uncertainty." Rubbish. Employers hire people when they don't have the staff to meet current or anticipated sales, and lay off workers when they don't have enough orders to keep them busy. No sensible capitalist would pass on the opportunity to make a buck, just because the cost goes up from 15 to 20 cents. Even if it costs 80 cents, that's still a 20% yield on investment.

Before you side with Woody Allen and his "plausible explanation", you may want to research the situation a bit.  If you read Dylan Farrow's rebuttal to this self-serving piece you will see that Woody has misrepresented quite a few things. 1. The child custody rulings back in 1993 document that Woody Allen was in therapy for "inappropriate" obsession with Dylan in 1991--a full year before Mia found the nude pictures of Soon-Yi and learned he was having an affair with her daughter.  Woody's article states that no on had accused him of molestation before or after was a lie. 2. The judge in the custody hearing (upheld by the appellate court) DID find cause for concern with Woody's obsession with Dylan and restricted his access to her, requiring supervised visits in a therapeutic setting. 3. The Yale-New Haven team's findings were not held t be credible by the judge, who said the findings were flawed by the members loyalty to Woody Allen and by their inappropriately overstepping their role. 4. Two adults that were present at Frog Hollow on the day of the molestation accusations reported seeing grossly inappropriate physical contact--Woody kneeling in front of Dylan with his head on her lap--and finding Dylan later without underpants.  Dylan later told the therapist that Woody had been blowing air at her private parts.  The babysitter also confirmed that both Woody and Dylan had been unaccounted for 20 minutes during the day--which supports Dylan's account.

I'm with Woody Allen - his reasonable explanation is plausible and reasoned. Mia Farrow lost me totally with her spiteful tweets - 21 years after the fact! - and throwing in the bit about their son Ronan possibly being Frank Sinatra's son is over the top. I hope the academy will judge Woody's work accordingly. His lifetime achievement award was well deserved.
What, Boehner became President when I was too busy working to read the newspaper?

It's all about the funneling of taxpayer dollars to for-profit private corporations.  These same corporations line the pocket of every politician and in turn own them outright.  Politicians no longer represent their constituents they sell their souls to the highest bidder.

@James,

No, no, nothing of the sort has happened. The laws passed by the House of Representatives, not the President allow outsourcing of national security functions to private companies.

The agent responsible for this fiasco is the same as one in Iraq. Why has our national security been outsourced to bumbling incompetents. Why are people not outraged that it continues, even though the majority of Americans want it stopped. Congress created the problem, has the power to stop it, but sits on their hands and does nothing. Speaker Boehner, stop outsourcing our nation's security.

Andrea

Americans have absorbed inequality for far too long. It's well past time, now that inequality is at its worst since we last had to fix it, to level the playing field. When so many have to work two and three low-wage jobs just to survive, when our kids - all of them - have to mortgage their entire working lives to pay for an education they cannot work without, when millions who work in retail, full time, have to depend on the rest of us to eat, it's time to make sure everyone who works, works for a living wage.

Snowden "...cost us millions..."
Every batch of papers released must cost the Dept of State, alone, over 1 $ million in man hours. That is repeated every month and State is a small player in this whole thing. Adding up what it will cost to replace compromised systems and the loss of intelligence resources, loss of business for US companies, etc. I think an independent assessor could point to more like a 10 $ billion in damages from the employee of Booze Allen Hamilton.

It's easy to support measures. The more, the merrier, and the greater their concern for humanity. There's no end to the number of measures that could be initiated. We could all become "helping" junkies if there were just more tax money to spend.

Someone has to consider the consequences, however. Liberals tend to focus only on the consequences of not implementing their desired policies.

One of the best things doctors and nurses can do for their patients is to let them know that they are welcome, and even expected, to ask questions.  Doctors can't know how much their patients and their families understand of what they are told.  But many people are hesitant to ask for explanations.

Great post.  To answer your question, I read where there was only ONE "terrorist" plot that was uncovered -  A transfer of $6000 to an organizaiton in Yemen that allegedly had ties with AQAP.  And there was no proof that this transfer funds was uncovered only because of the mass surveillance used by the NSA. Most likely it would have been discovered by traditional means of gathering information that didn't involve mass spying on Americans.
Well said, the angry mob is being led in the wrong direction. They should be chasing after the likes of Mike Rogers.
Sorry. but this data mining started under your pal G, W, Bush via the Patriot Act, which is anything but....  It opened the door to this massive spying on the citizens of this nation.

Edward Snowden explains in an interview with the world's 2nd largest publicly funded broadcast network, ARD, on the blog site, http://jessescrossroadscafe.blogspot.com/
The link: http://jessescrossroadscafe.blogspot.com/2014/02/snowden-interview-on-ge... - his reasons, rationales, motivations and in-depth articulations of why he did what he did, and who he did it for. Anyone with half a brain will get a clearer understanding of the background, the means and the direct results of exposure of government malfeasance and presidential criminality - if not outright impeachable offenses. As a sub-contractor, he reveals how the government, in an attempt to cut costs and redirect budgets to pet projects, allocated monies to no-bid outfits, like Booze Allen, to hire contractors to do the governments dirty works - and the consequences thereof.
The saddest part of the entire affaire is that the focus in the media is upon Snowden - and not upon the Obama Administration and their unconstitutional activities, as well as the total global surveillance that the NSA have been engaged in - not to prevent terrorism, but to target economic interests and competitors of US corporations, to give them the "edge" in the global marketplace. How many terrorist plots have they discovered? One or two.

Not so sure he got "caught on lies on the pages of the New York Times"... There were many sources never cited as well as quite a few pieces missing in the Vanity Fair pieces including this from the New York Times:
http://www.nytimes.com/books/97/02/23/reviews/farrow-doctor.html

I don't think we can conclude with certainty that he didn't do it, but the evidence is very conflicting. The Vanity Fair article is not beyond reproach in terms of accuracy and bias.

I think it's possible that both Mia Farrow and Woody Allen are innocent--that Mia Farrow truly believes he did something, and that Woody Allen truly did nothing. I can also understand why people really feel the evidence points one way or the other. Either way, it's tremendously tragic for Dylan Farrow--her suffering is real no matter what the truth is.
So you are employing projection to defame Mr Allen.

and I guess it's helpless - even if the man get's caught on lies on the pages of the New York Times - and another "Magazine" -(Vanity Fair) lists every single one of his lies...

There is still all this "Opinion" out there...
-(and actually that used to be my favorite defense - I always labeled my lies "opinion" too!)
